instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP0V9_SSD_REG: What is PP0V9_SSD_REG? PP0V9_SSD_REG is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD inside newer Macbooks. This must be present for the machine’s SSD to work. .
definitions.P2V7NAND_EN: What is P2V7NAND_EN? P2V7NAND_EN is a signal that enables the PP2V7_NAND power rail when it is high, which is a power rail necessary to turn on the SSD. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro mid 2017 no internal SSD/NAND <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hello people.

I've purchased this mid 2017 13" MacBook Pro touchbar, logic board number <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> who don't recognize internal SSD anymore. When powered on it display the question mark. Seller says that it simply stop working one day, no liquid spill, failed update or so. It can operate perfectly installing MacOs on external drive, but internal SSD storage does not show up in online recovery nor when external hard drive is plugged it to launch MacOs.

I decided to open it and try to resolve the problem. Never been opened or worked before for sure.

Inspecting the board under the microscope show this two little spot of corrosion:

probe point TP[1]<SIGNAL>TP_Q3100_DRAIN</SIGNAL> , picture show before and after cleaning
[ATTACH type="full"]60796[/ATTACH]
[ATTACH type="full"]60797[/ATTACH]
[ATTACH type="full"]60798[/ATTACH]
and LB300
[ATTACH type="full"]60799[/ATTACH]
[ATTACH type="full"]60800[/ATTACH]
I can't find any other spot or phisical damage on this board. 

J9600 (lifeboat port) also look good. 

I can confirm <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> ACE controller works fine, it does negotiate the 20V and I can boot up and charge the battery.

As mentionend many times as possible trouble point, <RESISTOR>R9350</RESISTOR> related to <SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL> measures 13.8V in both test point and pin1 and 1.58V on pin 2.

I'm not so good looking at schematics as this is not my work, just hobby for myself. I made those measurement taking a cue on other posts, so please forgive me if I'm completely wrong. Just wanna learn something and have fun.


<CAPACITOR>C9126</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD_COLD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V diode mode 294 (2K scale)
<CAPACITOR>C9304</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD_FIXED</SIGNAL> - 0.9V diode mode 294 (2K scale)
<CAPACITOR>C8724</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP1V2_SSD_HOT</SIGNAL> - 1.22V diode mode 328 (2K scale)
<CAPACITOR>C8714</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD_HOT</SIGNAL> - 1.8V diode mode 408 (2K scale)
<CAPACITOR>C8732</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP1V2_SSD_COLD</SIGNAL> - 1.22V diode mode 282 (2K scale)
<CAPACITOR>C9323</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD_REG</SIGNAL> - 0.9 diode mode 208 (2K scale)

I measured also <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SSD</SIGNAL> and it's 3.34V. 

I got 0 voltage at L9300/20/30/40 and L9400

<CAPACITOR>C9422</CAPACITOR>- PIN1 <SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND_VCC</SIGNAL> 4.8V

<SIGNAL>SSD_BOOT_LB_L</SIGNAL> 1.62V
<SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN_LB_L</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>STORAGE_LB_EN</SIGNAL> 3.05V
<SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_LB_L</SIGNAL> 3.05V
<SIGNAL>SSD_PCIE_CLKREQ_LB_L</SIGNAL> 3.18V
<SIGNAL>LPSR_EN_LB_L</SIGNAL> 3.05

at <RESISTOR>R9420</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>P2V7NAND_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PICCOLO_VEN1</SIGNAL> are 0V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro mid 2017 no internal SSD/NAND <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"<CAPACITOR>C9304</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD_FIXED</SIGNAL> - 0.9V diode mode 294 (2K scale)"
I'm not sure about your notations.
First, diode mode is not same as ohm (2K) scale; don't create more confusion.
Second, you've said 0V at L9300.

Please, post accurate information.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro mid 2017 no internal SSD/NAND <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Damn, I dunno what happened. I’m pretty sure the first time I had readings.

took measures again:
<CAPACITOR>C9126</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD_COLD</SIGNAL> - 0v
<CAPACITOR>C9304</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD_FIXED</SIGNAL> - 0V
<CAPACITOR>C8724</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP1V2_SSD_HOT</SIGNAL> - 0V
<CAPACITOR>C8714</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD_HOT</SIGNAL> - 0V
<CAPACITOR>C8732</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP1V2_SSD_COLD</SIGNAL> - 0v
<CAPACITOR>C9323</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD_REG</SIGNAL> - 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SSD</SIGNAL> and it's 3.34V.

I got 0 voltage at L9300/20/30/40 and L9400

<CAPACITOR>C9422</CAPACITOR>- PIN1 <SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND_VCC</SIGNAL> 4.8V

<SIGNAL>SSD_BOOT_LB_L</SIGNAL> 1.62V
<SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN_LB_L</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>STORAGE_LB_EN</SIGNAL> 3.05V
<SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_LB_L</SIGNAL> 3.05V
<SIGNAL>SSD_PCIE_CLKREQ_LB_L</SIGNAL> 3.18V
<SIGNAL>LPSR_EN_LB_L</SIGNAL> 3.05

at <RESISTOR>R9420</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>P2V7NAND_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PICCOLO_VEN1</SIGNAL> are 0V


For diode mode: Red probe on ground, black probe in test point. Multimeter setting in continuity mode. Sorry for confusion.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro mid 2017 no internal SSD/NAND <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Check if you have good contacts left/right for all lines of J9600.
If needed, remove the top plate and clean its contacts.

Inspect for corrosion on any trace SSD related; no matters if power rail, or signal line.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro mid 2017 no internal SSD/NAND <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Unfortunately my multimeters probe are not so small to let me check left/right J9600 pin inside connector, but it seems they are fine. I posted pictures of both connector and top plate. I cleaned both anyway.

I really can't find any corrosion anywhere.

But taking a look in <CHIP>U9400</CHIP>, it seems like it has an hole on it! And it become extremely hot.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro mid 2017 no internal SSD/NAND <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"Unfortunately my multimeters probe are not so small to let me check left/right J9600 pin inside connector"
I meant to check continuity for left/right lines with J9600 connected.
You can find test points, or components pins connected to corresponding lines for test.

However, as <CHIP>U9400</CHIP> is burnt, fix that problem first.
Replace <CHIP>U9400</CHIP> and check also <RESISTOR>R9401</RESISTOR>/06 values.
Be sure to get good solders; if not, risk to burn <TRANSISTOR>Q9401</TRANSISTOR> and NANDs.
